facts.text: Respondents purchased an omnibus for Rs. 14,500 in June 1950 to ply it as a stage carriage.

anchor.surface_text: In June, 1950 the respondents purchased an omnibus for Rs. 14,500 to ply it as a stage carriage.

facts.text: Respondents sold the omnibus together with the right to ply it for Rs. 23,000 on March 5, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On March 5, 1958 they sole the omnibus together with the right to ply it for Rs. 23,000.

facts.text: Before the date of the sale the price paid by the respondents was recouped out of the depreciation allowed in income-tax assessment proceedings and the written down value of the omnibus was nil.

anchor.surface_text: Before the date of the sale the price paid by the respondents was recouped out of the depreciation allowed in proceedings for assessment of income-tax and the written down value of the omnibus in the record of the income- tax office was nil.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed Rs. 14,500 as deemed profit under section 10(2)(vii) of the Income-tax Act, 1922 for assessment year 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment to income-tax for the assessment year 1959-60, the Income-tax Officer brought to tax Rs. 14,500 as deemed profit under section 10 2  vii  of the Income-tax Act, 1922,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed balance of Rs. 8,500 as income arising from carrying on trade for assessment year 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: and the balance of Rs. 8,500 as income arising from carrying on trade.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner substantially confirmed the Income-tax Officer's order.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner the order of the Income-tax Officer was substantially companyfirmed.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held excess over original price as capital gains not trading profits.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner however held that the excess over the original price of the omnibus represented number the trading profits but capital gains in respect of that omnibus.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held price received for sale of omnibus was Rs. 6,000 chargeable under section 10(2)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the Appellate Tribunal held that the price received by respondents for the sale of the omnibus was Rs. 6,000 and that amount was chargeable to income-tax under section 10 2   vii .

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held difference between Rs. 23,000 received and original price Rs. 14,500 as capital gain under section 12B.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal further held that the difference between the amount of Rs. 23,000 which was received by the respondents as companysideration for the sale and the original price of Rs. 14,500 represented capital gain chargeable to income-tax under section 12B 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court of Andhra Pradesh at instance of Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal then referred the following question at the instance of the Commissioner to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the excess of Rs. 17,000 over the deemed profits of Rs. 6,000 held to be taxable under section 10 2   vii  should wholly be treated as a capital gain liable to tax under section 12B of the Act ?

facts.text: High Court held amount received in excess over original value of omnibus as capital gain taxable under section 12B.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the amount received as price for sale in excess over the original value of the omnibus companyld be treated as capital gain and companyld be taxed but number the balance.

facts.text: Commissioner appealed to Supreme Court against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the High Court, the Commissioner has appealed to this companyrt.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer viewed sale of omnibus for Rs. 23,000.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer was apparently of the view that the respondent sold the omnibus for Rs. 23,000 and with that view the Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed.

facts.text: Tribunal held sale of omnibus was Rs. 6,000 and rest consideration for parting with right to ply under permit.

anchor.surface_text: But according to the Tribunal it was companyposite sale of the omnibus and of the right to ply the omnibus under the permit held by the omnibus was only Rs. 6,000 and the respondents had received companysideration for parting with the right to ply the omnibus under the permit granted to them.

facts.text: Tribunal held right to ply the omnibus was not property.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also held that the right to ply the omnibus was number property.

facts.text: Tribunal held Rs. 8,500 as capital gain under section 12B.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal still held that the amount of Rs. 8,500 which represented the difference between the companysideration for sale and the right to ply the omnibus and the original value of the omnibus was capital gain chargeable to tax under section 12B.

facts.text: Commissioner applied to Tribunal for reference under section 66(1) including question on whether route value constitutes asset or property.
